title: Hook flag mismatch: --no-git-history passed to bd import
description:
## Problem

The post-checkout hook calls:
```bash
bd sync --import-only --no-git-history
```

This fails because when `--import-only` is used, `bd sync` internally calls `bd import` and passes `--no-git-history` to it. But `bd import` doesn't have that flag.

## Error
```
Error importing: import failed: exit status 1
Error: unknown flag: --no-git-history
Usage:
  bd import [flags]
```

## Expected
`bd sync --import-only --no-git-history` should work, or the hook should use different flags.

## Workaround
The warning is harmless - `bd sync` works fine when called manually.

title: Hierarchical IDs create implicit parent-child not exposed by daemon API
notes:
## Summary
Hierarchical bead IDs (`<parent-id>.<N>`) create an **implicit** parent-child relationship based on ID naming convention. This implicit relationship:
1. Is NOT exposed through the daemon API
2. Blocks adding explicit `parent-child` dependencies
3. Results in "orphaned" parent-child relationships invisible to vscode-beads

## Reproduction
```bash
# Create parent
bd create --title="Parent" --type=epic
# Output: vsbeads-515e

# Create child with --parent (works correctly - adds BOTH hierarchical ID AND explicit dep)
bd create --title="Child" --type=task --parent=vsbeads-515e
# Output: vsbeads-515e.1 (hierarchical ID)
# Also adds explicit parent-child dependency record

# Try to manually add parent-child dep (BLOCKED)
bd dep add vsbeads-515e.1 vsbeads-515e --type=parent-child
# Error: cannot add dependency: vsbeads-515e.1 is already a child of vsbeads-515e.
# Children inherit dependency on parent completion via hierarchy.
# Adding an explicit dependency would create a deadlock
```

## Root Cause
The `isChildOf()` function checks if an ID follows hierarchical pattern (`parent.N`):
- If true, blocks adding explicit `parent-child` dependency (bd-nim5 fix)
- But daemon API doesn't synthesize this implicit relationship in dependency queries
- vscode-beads only sees explicit dependencies from daemon

## Upstream Code References
| File | Line | Function | Purpose |
|------|------|----------|---------|
| `cmd/bd/dep.go` | 30 | `isChildOf()` | Checks if ID follows hierarchical pattern |
| `cmd/bd/dep.go` | 142-146 | dep add | Blocks child→parent deps with deadlock error |
| `internal/rpc/server_labels_deps_comments.go` | 15-24 | `isChildOf()` | Same check in daemon RPC |
| `internal/rpc/server_labels_deps_comments.go` | 35-42 | `DepAdd()` | Daemon-side blocking |
| `internal/storage/sqlite/ids.go` | 44-64 | `IsHierarchicalID()` | Parses hierarchical IDs |
| `internal/storage/sqlite/ids.go` | 70-91 | `ParseHierarchicalID()` | Extracts parent ID and child number |

## Impact
- Issues imported with hierarchical IDs (e.g., from Linear) may lack explicit dependencies
- Parent-child relationships invisible in vscode-beads UI
- Cannot manually fix by adding dependency (blocked)
- Dependency display shows "-" for parent/children columns

## Possible Solutions
1. **Upstream fix**: Daemon API should synthesize implicit parent-child from hierarchical IDs
2. **vscode-beads workaround**: Parse hierarchical IDs client-side to infer relationships
3. **Data migration**: Script to add missing explicit deps for existing hierarchical IDs

## Related
- bd-nim5: Original fix that added the blocking behavior
- GH#728: Child counter updates for explicit child IDs
- `bd doctor --fix-child-parent`: Opt-in fix for child→parent deps
close_reason: Testing shows mechanism works correctly. Will file new issue if reproduction steps found in other project.

title: Mutation watch spams errors when daemon dies
description:
When the beads daemon is killed, the extension spams error output repeatedly:

```
[ProjectManager] Mutation watch error: Socket error: connect ENOENT /Users/jason/ws/jdillon/vscode-beads/.beads/bd.sock
[ProjectManager] Mutation watch error: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'filter')
```

The "filter" error repeats continuously.
design:
## Root Cause

1. **Error spam** (`BeadsDaemonClient.ts:490-510`): `startMutationWatch` used `setInterval` polling every 1s. When daemon dies, every poll failed with socket error - interval kept running forever.

2. **Null filter error** (`BeadsDaemonClient.ts:495`): `mutations.filter()` called but `getMutations` could return null if daemon returned `{success: true}` without data.

3. **No status feedback**: When daemon died, `daemonStatus` never updated.

## Fix Implemented

**BeadsDaemonClient.ts:**
- Null guards on all array-returning methods (`list`, `ready`, `listComments`, `getMutations`)
- Replaced `setInterval` with `setTimeout` + exponential backoff (1s -> 2s -> 4s -> ... -> 30s max)
- Added `disconnected` and `reconnected` events (emit only on state change)
- Track connection state to avoid duplicate events

**BeadsProjectManager.ts:**
- Listen for `disconnected`/`reconnected` events instead of generic `error`
- Update `project.daemonStatus` on disconnect/reconnect
- Fire `onActiveProjectChanged` to update UI
acceptance_criteria:
- [x] Null guards prevent "Cannot read properties of null (reading 'filter')" error
- [x] Exponential backoff prevents error spam (1s -> 30s max)
- [x] Single "Daemon disconnected" message on disconnect
- [x] Single "Daemon reconnected" message on reconnect
- [x] daemonStatus updates to "stopped"/"running" appropriately
- [ ] Status bar icon changes color on disconnect (UI needs to consume daemonStatus)

title: Release workflow: local slash command with changelog validation
description:
Replace `workflow_dispatch` with tag-triggered workflow. Add `/release` slash command for local release management.

## Current problems
- Must go to GitHub to trigger release
- Version auto-calculated after publish → can't finalize changelog first
- Post-release version bump creates chicken/egg with changelog

## Solution

### `/release` slash command
1. **Compute default version** based on branch:
   - `main` → bump minor (0.1.3 → 0.2.0)
   - `release-v*` → bump patch (0.2.0 → 0.2.1)
   - Present as default, allow override

2. **Audit changelog** for missing entries:
   - Parse git log since last tag
   - Compare to changelog entries
   - Flag potential gaps (feat/fix commits not in changelog)
   - Skip: docs, chore, refactor, ci commits
   - If gaps → ask user to update first

3. **Validate & execute**:
   - Verify `[Unreleased]` has content
   - Move `[Unreleased]` → `[X.Y.Z] - YYYY-MM-DD`
   - Update `package.json` version
   - Commit: `chore: release vX.Y.Z`
   - Tag: `vX.Y.Z`
   - Push branch + tag

### GitHub workflow changes
- Trigger: `on: push: tags: 'v*'`
- Remove: version calculation, post-publish bump
- Keep: build, lint, package, publish, create release

title: "Active" filter includes blocked issues - should it?
description:
## Problem

The "Active" filter currently includes issues with `status=blocked`. This pollutes the list with items that can't be worked on.

## Intent of "Active"

"Active" was created to fill the gap between:
- `bd ready` = open + no blockers (things to pick up)
- `bd list --status=in_progress` = things currently being worked

Neither shows both. "Active" should be: **ready + in_progress** = everything I can touch today.

## Current Behavior

`bd list --status=active` returns:
- `open` (all, not just unblocked)
- `in_progress`
- `blocked` ← shouldn't be here

## Expected Behavior

"Active" should return:
- `open` with no blockers (i.e., ready)
- `in_progress`

Excludes:
- `blocked` (stalled, can't work on)
- `open` with unresolved blockers (also can't work on)

## Fix

Change "Active" filter logic to: `(status=open AND no_blockers) OR status=in_progress`

title: Fix confusing dependency type handling and parent-child usage
description:
Dependency handling is confusing in multiple ways:

**Problem 1: Directional confusion**
- `blocks` relationship is the same whether viewed as "depends on" or "blocks"
- UI shows "Depends On" and "Blocks" sections but both use `blocks` type
- Not clear to users that these are the same underlying relationship

**Problem 2: Not using parent-child for epics**
- We have epics (e.g., vsbeads-5c0) with child tasks
- But agent creates them with `blocks` dependencies, not `parent-child`
- Should epics use `parent-child` type? What's the semantic difference?

**Problem 3: Unclear when to use each type**
- `blocks` - hard blocker, affects ready queue
- `related` - soft link, context only
- `parent-child` - epic/subtask hierarchy
- `discovered-from` - work found during other work

When should agent use parent-child vs blocks vs discovered-from?

**Potential fixes:**
1. Add dependency graph visualization showing relationships clearly
2. Update CLAUDE.md/agent instructions on when to use each type
3. Clarify UI labels (maybe show relationship type, not just direction)
4. Consider migrating existing epic→task relationships to parent-child
design:
## Correct Usage (from beads docs)

**`blocks`** - Hard blocker between independent issues
- "Task A blocks Task B" = B can't start until A is done
- Both directions affect ready queue

**`parent-child`** - Epic/subtask hierarchy
- `bd dep add EPIC_ID TASK_ID --type parent-child`
- Epic is parent, tasks are children
- Special behaviors:
  - `bd epic status` shows progress/completion %
  - `bd epic close-eligible` auto-closes complete epics
  - Children blocked if parent is blocked
- **We should use this for epics, not `blocks`!**

**`related`** - Soft link for context
- Doesn't affect ready queue
- Just for reference/navigation

**`discovered-from`** - Work discovered during other work
- Tracks "yak shaving" chains
- `bd dep tree --reverse` shows discovery tree

## Current Problem

Agent creates epic relationships with `blocks` but should use `parent-child`:
```bash
# Wrong (what we do now):
bd dep add vsbeads-5c0 vsbeads-yjr --type blocks

# Right (what we should do):
bd dep add vsbeads-5c0 vsbeads-yjr --type parent-child
```

## Fixes Needed

1. Update CLAUDE.md with dependency type guidance
2. Fix vscode-beads MCP tools to support `--type` parameter
3. Consider graph view showing relationship types with different edge styles
notes:
## Upstream Bug: `bd show` mislabels dependency types

From `sandbox/bd-show-display-bug.md`:

**Bug:** `bd show` displays ALL dependencies under "Blocks" header, regardless of actual type.

```
$ bd show platform-wue

Blocks (10):           # WRONG - these are parent-child!
  ← platform-1pi: ...
```

**Actual data in beads.jsonl:**
```json
{"issue_id":"platform-1pi","depends_on_id":"platform-wue","type":"parent-child",...}
```

**Expected:**
```
Children (10):
  ← platform-1pi: ...
```

## Impact on vscode-beads

The `--json` output should include `dependency_type` field. We can:
1. Use `dependency_type` from JSON to display correctly in UI
2. Group by type: "Children", "Blocks", "Related", "Discovered From"
3. Different visual styling per type (icons, colors)

## Action Items

1. **Upstream:** File bug/PR for `bd show` to respect dependency type in display
2. **vscode-beads:** Use `dependency_type` from daemon API to display correctly
3. **vscode-beads:** Show relationship type in UI (badge, icon, or section header)

title: Research: Better beads workflow to avoid PR/branch conflicts
description:
Beads conflates PR/branch workflows with issue tracker changes, causing beads created in feature branches to be auto-deleted when PRs merge.

**Problem:**
- Beads created in feature branch get committed with code
- PR merges bring beads into main via git
- `bd sync --from-main` runs and treats these as "foreign" entries
- git-history-backfill incorrectly deletes them as "pruned from manifest"

**Analysis:** See `tmp/beads-deletion-analysis.md`
**Full discussion:** See `tmp/session-subagent-discussion.jsonl`

**Potential Solutions to Research:**

1. **Protected branch support** - beads has this feature, unclear if it helps
   - Does it prevent sync from touching certain branches?
   - Can it isolate beads changes from code changes?

2. **Dedicated beads branch** - worktree with separate branch just for .beads/
   - Code stays on feature branches
   - Beads always committed to a single branch (e.g., `beads-main`)
   - Avoids merge conflicts between code PRs and beads state

3. **Gitignore .beads/ in feature branches**
   - Only commit beads on main
   - Feature branches inherit but don't modify
   - Sync happens only on main

4. **Submodule approach** - .beads/ as separate git repo
   - Complete isolation of issue tracker from code
   - More complex setup

> submodule is probably not great sub modules tie to revisions and the revision of this will be constantly changing.

**Goal:** Find a workflow where:
- Beads can be created/updated during feature work
- PRs don't bring stale/conflicting beads state
- No accidental deletions via sync
design:
## Research Findings

### Question: Is it by design that all branches carry beads changes?

**Answer: NO - this is incidental and problematic, not by design.**

### Evidence from GitHub Issues

1. **Issue #207 (Using beads with PRs)** - Steve Yegge (Nov 4): "We're taking a serious look at offering a multi-repo solution, where beads uses separate repos"

2. **Issue #195 (.beads as worktree on orphan branch)** - Steve Yegge (Nov 4): Rejected worktree approach as "too git-centric", pursuing separate repository option instead for:
   - Clean separation of issue tracking from code history
   - Platform-agnostic approach (VCS-independent)
   - Better monorepo/multi-project support

3. **Issue #158 (Merge conflicts)** - Extensive discussion about multi-agent conflicts, led to improved 3-way merging in v0.24.1+

### Currently Supported Solutions

1. **Protected Branch Workflow** (`bd init --branch beads-metadata`):
   - Beads commits to separate branch via git worktrees
   - Code stays on feature branches
   - Periodically merge beads-metadata → main via PR
   - See: docs/PROTECTED_BRANCHES.md

2. **Contributor Workflow** (`bd init --contributor`):
   - For OSS contributors
   - Issues stored in `~/.beads-planning` (separate local repo)
   - Never pollutes upstream PRs

### Our Specific Bug

The `git-history-backfill` deleting beads from PRs appears to be a **bug**, not intended behavior:
- Expected: Beads in git history should be **recovered** (added to local DB)
- Actual: Beads are **deleted** as "pruned from manifest"

### Recommendation

Try protected branch workflow:
```bash
bd config set sync.branch beads-metadata
bd daemon restart
```

Consider filing bug report for git-history-backfill behavior.
notes:
## Decision (2025-11-28)

**Strategy:** Try protected branch workflow now, wait for upstream multi-repo solution.

## Experiment on forge (2025-11-28)

Tested `bd config set sync.branch beads-metadata` with `--auto-commit --auto-push`:

**What works:**
- ✅ Beads commits go to `beads-metadata` branch (via worktree)
- ✅ Auto-push to `origin/beads-metadata` works
- ✅ `main` branch stays untouched (no new commits)

**Issues found:**
- ❌ Working tree still shows `.beads/beads.jsonl` modified (tracked on main)
  - Fix: untrack from main with `git rm --cached`
- ❌ `beads-metadata` is NOT an orphan branch - it's a snapshot of main at config time
  - Contains full code tree + history
  - Designed for merge workflow, not true isolation
  - For "never merge" approach, this is wasteful/messy

**Branch structure:**
```
main ─────────────────────────────────► (gets beads.jsonl changes in working tree)
         \
          └─ beads-metadata ──────────► (beads commits here, has full code copy)
```

**What we'd want (orphan):**
```
main ──────────────────► (code only)
beads-metadata (orphan) ──────────────► (beads only, no shared history)
```

Issue #195 proposed orphan approach but Steve rejected as "too git-centric" - pursuing separate repo instead.

**Status:** Experiment complete, need to decide:
1. Live with non-orphan branch (functional but messy)
2. DIY orphan branch (unsupported)
3. Wait for upstream multi-repo

## Implementation (2025-11-29)

Successfully migrated vscode-beads to protected branch workflow:
- Untracked beads.jsonl/deletions.jsonl from main
- Set sync.branch = beads-metadata
- Daemon runs with --auto-commit --auto-push
- Updated docs/development.md with setup instructions

There's upstream inconsistency about whether the JSONL file should be named `beads.jsonl` or `issues.jsonl`. Got conflicting answers from maintainers. Leaving as-is until upstream clarifies the canonical naming.

description:
Research and prototype automated end-to-end testing for the VS Code extension using Playwright with code-server.

**Why Playwright:**
- Microsoft recommends Playwright for VS Code extension testing
- Headless browser automation with excellent TypeScript support
- Can interact with webviews, which is critical for our React-based UI
- Built-in waiting/retry mechanisms

**Areas to investigate:**

1. **Test setup architecture**
   - How to start/stop code-server programmatically in tests
   - Extension installation/symlink setup in CI
   - Fixture management for test beads data

2. **Webview testing**
   - Accessing webview iframes in Playwright
   - Testing React components through the webview boundary
   - Handling postMessage communication

3. **Integration patterns**
   - Testing daemon start/stop/status flows
   - Mock vs real `bd` CLI for tests
   - Snapshot testing for UI states

4. **CI integration**
   - GitHub Actions setup for headless Playwright
   - Test parallelization strategies
   - Artifact capture (screenshots, traces) on failure

**Alternatives to evaluate:**
- @vscode/test-electron (official but less webview support)
- Selenium (older, less recommended)
- Puppeteer (similar to Playwright but less features)

**Resources:**
- https://playwright.dev/docs/intro
- https://code.visualstudio.com/api/working-with-extensions/testing-extension
- Chrome DevTools MCP could potentially be used for manual testing augmentation
notes:
## Research Findings (2025-12-05)

### Playwright + code-server Strategy Validated

This approach is viable and aligns with Microsoft's recommendations for testing VS Code extensions that use webviews.

**Key findings:**
1. **Playwright handles iframes well** - Critical for webview testing. Use `page.frameLocator()` or `page.frame({ url })` to access webview content
2. **Bun support exists** - `bun create playwright` or manual setup with `@playwright/test`
3. **GitHub Actions recommended pattern** - Use `npx playwright install --with-deps`, NOT the deprecated GitHub Action
4. **code-server compatibility** - Similar to OpenVSCode Server; both expose VS Code in browser which Playwright can automate

### Test Architecture Recommendations

```
e2e/
├── playwright.config.ts      # Config: baseURL, projects, timeouts
├── fixtures/
│   ├── code-server.ts        # Custom fixture: start/stop code-server
│   └── beads-project.ts      # Fixture: scaffold test .beads directory
├── helpers/
│   ├── webview.ts            # Helper: locate webview frames
│   └── selectors.ts          # Shared selectors for UI elements
└── tests/
    ├── issues-view.spec.ts   # Issues panel tests
    ├── details-view.spec.ts  # Details panel tests
    └── daemon.spec.ts        # Daemon start/stop tests
```

### Key Challenges to Address

1. **Webview frame access** - VS Code embeds webviews in iframes; need to reliably locate them
2. **Test data isolation** - Each test needs clean beads project state
3. **code-server lifecycle** - Start before tests, stop after
4. **CI timing** - code-server startup takes time; need proper wait strategies

- [Playwright Installation](https://playwright.dev/docs/intro)
- [Playwright Frame Handling](https://playwright.dev/docs/frames)
- [Playwright CI Setup](https://playwright.dev/docs/ci)
- [Playwright + Bun Template](https://github.com/fabianmolinab/playwright-bun-template)

title: Implicit parent-child from hierarchical IDs not reflected in daemon/UI
notes:
## Problem
Hierarchical bead IDs (e.g., `bd-abc.1`, `bd-abc.2`) create an **implicit** parent-child relationship based purely on the ID naming convention. This implicit relationship:

1. **Blocks adding explicit dependencies** - Trying to add a parent-child dependency returns: "cannot add dependency: X is already a child of Y. Children inherit dependency via hierarchy."
2. **May not be reflected in daemon/UI** - The implicit relationship from ID naming may not be exposed through the daemon API, so vscode-beads can't display it

## How Hierarchical IDs Work (upstream beads)
- When creating with `--parent`, `bd create` does TWO things:
  1. Generates hierarchical ID: `parent-id.N` (e.g., `vsbeads-515e.1`)
  2. Adds explicit `parent-child` type dependency
- The `isChildOf()` function in `dep.go` and `server_labels_deps_comments.go` checks if an ID follows the hierarchical pattern
- Fix bd-nim5 added validation to prevent "deadlock" from explicit deps on implicit relationships

## Key Code Locations (upstream)
- `cmd/bd/dep.go:30` - `isChildOf()` function
- `cmd/bd/dep.go:142-146` - Check that blocks child→parent deps
- `internal/rpc/server_labels_deps_comments.go:15-24` - Same check in daemon
- `internal/storage/sqlite/ids.go:44-64` - `IsHierarchicalID()` parsing

## Impact on vscode-beads
If issues have hierarchical IDs but the daemon doesn't expose the implicit parent-child relationship:
- Parent/child won't show in dependency display
- Can't manually add the relationship (blocked)
- Possible data inconsistency

## Investigation Needed
- Check if daemon returns implicit hierarchy in dependency queries
- Verify how Linear imports or other sources create hierarchical IDs
- Determine if this is an upstream beads issue or vscode-beads display issue

title: viewContainer/title buttons not showing in BEADS header

notes:
**Finding:** This is a VS Code platform limitation, not a bug in our extension.

Per [microsoft/vscode#74221](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/74221):
- Built-in view containers (Run and Debug, Search) can have title bar buttons
- Extension view containers can ONLY add to overflow menu (...)
- Feature request was rejected as "out-of-scope"

**Current workaround:** Use `view/title` to add buttons to individual view headers (e.g., Issues panel title bar) instead of the container title bar.

**Status:** Won't fix - VS Code limitation

title: Test: code-server for native macOS dev with bd socket access
description:
Test code-server (Coder) running natively on macOS for vscode-beads development.

## Motivation
- openvscode-server only available via Docker on macOS
- Docker isolation blocks bd daemon socket access
- code-server runs natively, should have full socket access

## Setup
```bash
brew install code-server
code-server --bind-addr localhost:8080
```

## Test Plan
1. Install code-server via brew
2. Start on localhost:8080
3. Install vscode-beads VSIX
4. Verify Beads panel connects to bd daemon
5. Test Chrome DevTools MCP integration
6. Document CLI options for extension management

## Success Criteria
- Extension loads
- Webviews work  
- bd daemon socket connects (no ECONNREFUSED)
- Issues display in panel
notes:
## Results - SUCCESS ✅

### Setup
```bash
brew install code-server
code-server --bind-addr localhost:8080 --auth none /path/to/project
```

### CLI Extension Management
```bash
code-server --install-extension /path/to/extension.vsix
code-server --list-extensions
```

### Why It Works
code-server runs natively on macOS, so it has direct access to the Unix socket at `.beads/bd.sock`. No Docker isolation.

### Dev Workflow
1. `bun run watch` (local rebuild)
2. `bun run package` (create VSIX)
3. `code-server --install-extension vscode-beads-*.vsix`
4. DevTools MCP: "Developer: Reload Window"
5. Test extension in browser
